text.speaker: Director
text: Hello, everyone. Welcome to the University of Orleans, a place where imagination meets logic and where every bug is an opportunity for creativity.
This year, as every year, we will explore fascinating areas: from artificial intelligence to distributed systems, from web development to quantum architectures that are still somewhat mysterious.
But beyond languages and frameworks, what we seek to impart to you is critical thinking, curiosity, and the ability to solve problems... even those that seem impossible at first glance. Thank you.

text.speaker: Professor
text.text: I am your formal calculation professor, Antoine Robert. I used to be just like you: a student at this university, sitting in the same seats as you. By listening to lectures and working hard, I managed to get this teaching position. I am now a research professor, which involves...

text: - ... teaching in schools while conducting research the rest of the time. Now that you know about my background, I will discuss the content of my course.
We will have a final exam at the end of the semester and about ten tutorials and practical classes to prepare for it. Each class will be divided into two parts -...

text.text: You have not received approval from the departmental council to enter the second year.
[I wait for the end of the day with a knot in my stomach. It takes me several hours to fully realize what is happening.]

text: [Rejected... I thought it would be a shock... but actually, it's more of a strange mix of feelings. Surprise... and at the same time, not really. In high school, I was good. Really good. Everyone told me I had potential, that I was “cut out for studying.” Yet I completely dropped out.]

[The truth is... I wasn't interested. I tried to convince myself otherwise, I followed the path everyone expected of me, but every class seemed... empty. Far from what I really wanted to do. And of course, because I wasn't motivated... I didn't give it my all. I did the bare minimum, sometimes nothing at all. How could I have succeeded like that? It wasn't for me. And I only realize that now, too late.]

text: [How could I explain this to my parents? “I failed because I didn't really believe in it”? That sounds so ridiculous... I need to ask myself the right questions.]

What do I want to do? What really motivates me? Continuing down a path that doesn't suit me will only lead to more failures. Well... I need to find something that suits me. And this time... I need to really commit to it.
[I spent the night researching. With Parcoursup closing several weeks ago, it will be very difficult for me to find a program that will accept me.]

[Why didn't I realize I was heading straight for disaster earlier this year? I'm forced to turn to subjects that rarely fill up classes and accept any grades, such as literature or history. I'm far from my ideal, but you never know! Maybe I'm actually cut out for this kind of study. It's totally different from computer science, after all!]

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: What? You weren't accepted? But… why?
I… I didn't invest enough in my studies. I had trouble getting interested in what I was doing and… I didn't give my best.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Oh… my dear… We knew it could be tough, but… hearing that hurts.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: We are disappointed, yes! But ... We really believed you could succeed. It's not just about disappointment for you… we're sad to see you suffer and lose confidence.
I'm sorry.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Listen… it's not the end of the world. You made a mistake, that's all. But you need to understand what didn't work to improve the situation. We'll look at the possible options for you together.
I want to give myself fully this time. I don't want to make the same mistakes.

text: [I thought it would be a disaster… that it would end in screams, accusations, ... But… they didn't reject me. They wanted to understand. They listened to me. They even told me they still believe in me.]
[I did well by confessing. In any case, hiding it wouldn't have changed anything… and now, at least, I'm not alone anymore. I feel like I've finally stopped running away.]

[What do I want to do? What truly motivates me? Continuing in a path that doesn’t suit me will only lead to more failures. Well… I need to find something that suits me. And this time… I’ll actually commit.]
[I spent the night researching. With the closure of Parcoursup several weeks ago, it will be very difficult for me to find a program that accepts me.]

[Why didn’t I realize earlier this year that I was heading straight into a wall?!... I’m forced to turn towards studies that rarely have full classes and accept students regardless of grades, like literature or history. I’m far from my ideal, but you never know! Maybe in fact, I’m made for this kind of study. It’s totally different from computer science, after all!]

text.text: The protagonist confides in his parents.
[I have to face up to it. I'll never be able to make a fresh start if I hide something this important from my own parents.]

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Hi sweetheart! Are you okay? You seem... worried.
Yes… I received the response for my passage to the second year.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: Finally. So? Is it okay?
…No. I was refused.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: What? You weren’t accepted? But… why?
I... I didn't put enough effort into my studies. I had trouble getting interested in what I was doing and... I didn't give it my best.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Oh... my dear. We knew it could be difficult, but... hearing it hurts.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: We are disappointed, yes! But ... we really believed you could succeed. It's not just about disappointment for you… we're also sad to see you suffer and lose confidence.
I'm sorry.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Listen... it's not the end of the world. You made a mistake, that's all. But you need to realize what went wrong so you can improve the situation. We'll look at the options available to you together.
I want to give it my all this time. I don't want to make the same mistakes again.

text: [They... supported me. They really understood. I thought they would be disappointed, that they would blame me for my choices... But they listened to me. They believed me. And they didn't minimize what I had been through.]
[I did the right thing by coming clean. Hiding it wouldn't have changed anything anyway... and now, at least, I'm not alone anymore. I feel like I've finally stopped running away.]

text.text: Haha! So you're better than me, are you?
[I wait for the end of the day with a knot in my stomach, enduring my friends' mockery. It takes me several hours to fully realize what is happening.]

text: [Rejected... I thought it would be a shock... but actually, it's more of a strange mix of feelings. Surprise... and at the same time, not really. In highschool, I was good. Really good. Everyone told me I had potential, that I was “cut out for studying.” ]
[This year, as every year, we will explore fascinating areas: from artificial intelligence to distributed systems, from web development to quantum architectures that are still somewhat mysterious.]

[Yet I completely dropped out. The truth is... I wasn't interested. I tried to convince myself otherwise, I followed the path everyone expected of me, but every class seemed... empty. Far from what I really wanted to do. And of course, because I wasn't motivated... ]

[I didn't give it my all. I did the bare minimum, sometimes nothing at all. How could I have succeeded like that? It wasn't for me. And I only realize that now, too late.]

text.text: The protagonist confides in his parents.
[But I can no longer continue to hide the situation from them. Pretending that I'm coping, that I'm holding up... is exhausting. And it's even harder now that I know I've failed.]

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Hi sweetheart! Are you okay? You seem...worried.
Yes... I received the answer regarding my transition to the second year.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: Finally. So? Is it good?
…No. I was refused.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Oh… sweetheart…

I... I'm sorry. I did everything I could, but between classes and work... I couldn't do it anymore. I was coming home too late, I was exhausted, I couldn't even study properly anymore. I tried to keep going, I really did... but I couldn't.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: You don't have to apologize. You fought to get out of it, you worked hard to earn your money and follow your studies. It's not your fault. It was just... too much for you.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: We saw how exhausted you were these past few months. You couldn't carry everything on your own. We're proud of you, do you hear me? Not disappointed. Proud of your courage.
I thought that... you would be angry with me. That you would be disappointed in me.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: Disappointed? Come on... You worked hard, you took responsibility, you did your best in a difficult situation. It's not a shameful failure. Even adults don't always manage to handle things so well.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: We'll think together about what you want to do. Whether it's starting over, changing your path, or lightening your workload… You're not alone.

text: [They... supported me. They really understood. I thought they would be disappointed, that they would blame me for my choices... But they listened to me. They believed me. And they didn't minimize what I had been through.]

[I did the right thing telling them. I had kept it all to myself for so long, carrying this burden alone... I feel lighter now. I am not alone. They are with me, and I will start over without making any more mistakes.]
